an6.43:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an6.43:1.2: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
an6.43:1.3: Then, after the meal, on his return from alms-round, he addressed Venerable Ānanda,
an6.43:1.4: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother for the day’s meditation.”
an6.43:2.1: So the Buddha went with Ānanda to the Eastern Monastery.
an6.43:2.2: In the late afternoon the Buddha came out of retreat and addressed Ānanda,
an6.43:2.3: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the eastern gate to bathe.”
an6.43:2.5: So the Buddha went with Ānanda to the eastern gate to bathe.
an6.43:2.6: When he had bathed and emerged from the water he stood in one robe drying himself.
an6.43:3.1: Now, at that time King Pasenadi had a giant bull elephant called “White”. It emerged from the eastern gate to the beating and playing of musical instruments.
an6.43:3.2: When people saw it they said,
an6.43:3.3: “The royal giant is so handsome! The royal giant is so good-looking! The royal giant is so lovely! The royal giant has such a huge body!”
an6.43:3.4: When they said this, Venerable Udāyī said to the Buddha,
an6.43:3.5: “Sir, is it only when they see elephants with such a huge, formidable body that people say:
an6.43:3.6: ‘A giant, such a giant’? Or do they say it when they see any other creatures with huge, formidable bodies?”
an6.43:3.7: “Udāyī, when they see elephants with such a huge, formidable body people say:
an6.43:3.9: And also when they see a horse with a huge, formidable body …
an6.43:3.10: When they see a bull with a huge, formidable body …
an6.43:3.11: When they see a snake with a huge, formidable body …
an6.43:3.12: When they see a tree with a huge, formidable body …
an6.43:3.13: And when they see a human being with such a huge, formidable body people say:
an6.43:3.15: But Udāyī, one who does nothing monstrous by way of body, speech, and mind is who I call a ‘giant’ in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.”
an6.43:4.2: How well said this was by the Buddha:
an6.43:4.3: ‘But Udāyī, one who does nothing monstrous by way of body, speech, and mind is who I call a “giant” in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.’
an6.43:4.4: And I celebrate the well-spoken words of the Buddha with these verses:
